I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Cook Islands for the COVID-19 Active Response and Economic Support (CARES) Program 
under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 Pandemic Response Option (CPRO).1 
 
2.  The program is part of a coordinated package of Asian Development Bank (ADB) support 
to mitigate the severe socioeconomic and potential health impacts caused by the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic by supporting the government’s Economic Response Plan (ERP).2 
The program will help the government combat the entry and spread of COVID-19 and provide 
assistance to vulnerable groups, households, and businesses. This program is critical because 
the Cook Islands faces significant declines in international tourism and government revenue 
because of COVID-19.  
 
3.   The program is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities of addressing 
remaining  poverty  and  reducing  inequalities,  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality, 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and fostering regional cooperation and 
integration.3 It is also aligned with the Pacific Approach priorities of managing risks and building 
 
resilience by strengthening the health sector and social protection.4 The Cook Islands meets all 
the access criteria of ADB’s CPRO under the Countercyclical Support Facility (Table 1).

II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
4.  Development context. The Cook Islands consists of 15 islands with a land area of 67 
square kilometers, spread across 2 million square kilometers of the South Pacific Ocean. Almost 
80% of the population of 17,434 in 2020 resides in Rarotonga. The shift in economic structure 
toward tourism since the late 1990s has led to rapid development, with basic needs poverty falling 
from 28.4% in 2006 to 8.4% by 2016. The Cook Islands is one of the smallest and most remote 
nations in the Pacific Ocean, with high cost structures and limited natural resources. The economy 
remains  heavily  dependent  on  international  trade  (including  tourism);  and  future  growth  is 
hampered by disproportionately expensive public administration and infrastructure costs, a small 
population, and high exposure to disaster and climate risks. The Cook Islands is not a member of 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank, so it has limited access to external 
support.  
 
5.  Preemptive health response. The Cook Islands has avoided a COVID-19 outbreak 
within its borders. With the global outbreak of the pandemic, the Ministry of Health (MOH) 
activated the Health Emergency Response System in January 2020.5 Following the progressive 
tightening of controls, including ceasing domestic travel, the border was completely closed to non-
residents on 24 March (Table 1). On the same day, a mandatory 14-day quarantine was

implemented for incoming residents, schools were closed, and social distancing was enforced.6 
Widespread testing began in mid-March, and the Cook Islands declared itself free of COVID-19 
on 16 April. Domestic controls have been relaxed, but the border remains closed.  
 
6.  Vulnerable  health  system.  The  high  prevalence  of  hypertension,  diabetes,  and 
cardiovascular  diseases  in  the  Cook  Islands  makes  it  more  vulnerable  to  COVID-19.  The 
Rarotonga Hospital, the nation’s main health facility, has a capacity of about 170 beds, with 32 
repurposed  into  an  isolation  ward  for  potential  COVID-19  cases.  The  estimated  potential 
requirement for hospital beds is about double the current capacity, and there are only three 
ventilators.7 Hotels have been identified to provide screening and quarantine, and there is one 
GeneXpert machine  for  processing  COVID-19 tests (although  most  tests  are  sent to  New 
Zealand). Health care is publicly funded, with services provided for free or for nominal fees. The 
skilled  health  professionals  density  of  7.0  per  1,000  population  is  above  the  Sustainable 
Development Goal minimum threshold of 4.45 per 1,000 population, but it relies on rotational staff 
from New Zealand for acute care and surgical services. These services are presently on hold, 
adding to the pressure on health workers. The majority of the health care workforce has had 
additional training in pandemic response, but the high infection rate of COVID-19 could rapidly 
deplete the workforce.  
 
7.  Tourism significantly affected. The Cook Islands is among the most tourism-driven 
economies in the Pacific region, with tourism receipts equivalent to 61.4% of annual gross 
domestic product (GDP) in FY2019. New Zealand is the primary tourism market, accounting for 
67% of FY2019 arrivals. The economy enjoyed sustained growth averaging 4.9% of GDP 
between FY2012 and FY2019 as visitor arrivals rose from 113,129 in 2011 to a peak of 171,550 
in 2019. From July 2019 to February 2020, visitor arrivals were 5.3% higher than the same period 
in the previous year. However, with borders closed to non-residents since March 2020, visitor 
arrivals have fallen to almost zero. The Cook Islands’ economic trajectory is tied to efforts to 
reopen its border with New Zealand. With closed borders, the potential impacts on livelihoods and 
businesses are severe even with government stimulus; each month that the border is closed, the 
economy is estimated to lose an additional 3% of its annual GDP.8 Since there is no central bank, 
the banking sector relies on public sector liquidity, with a fiscal crisis likely to be exacerbated by 
a financial crisis if public reserves are depleted before economic recovery takes hold. Supply 
disruptions have impacted imports, but local value chains are largely tied to tourism activity. 
 
8.  Unprecedented  economic  losses.  ADB  estimates  that  GDP  fell  7.0%  in  FY2020 
because of the impact of COVID-19 on visitor arrivals in the fourth quarter, a dramatic turnaround 
from the 4.5% growth projected in December 2019.9 Even if the border were to open to tourism 
in January 2021, ADB estimates that GDP would fall a further 15.4% in FY2021, despite extensive 
government stimulus efforts. The decline would be the largest in Cook Islands’ history, negatively 
impacting employment, business viability, government finances, and social wellbeing.  
 
9.  Pre-shock record of sound economic management. Over FY2016–FY2019, the fiscal 
surplus averaged 5.7% (Table 2). Revenue performed strongly, especially following tax reforms 
in 2014, with domestic revenue increasing from 39.1% of GDP in FY2016 to 41.0% of GDP in

10.  Sharp reversal of fiscal performance. The collapse of the tourism industry will have a 
dramatic impact on government tax collection (71.9% of total government revenue in FY2019). 
After falling to 28.2% of GDP in FY2020, tax receipts are estimated to decline to 21.2% of GDP 
in FY2021. Expenditure is expected to grow from 49.5% of GDP in FY2020 to 72.7% of GDP in 
FY2021 because of the countercyclical expenditure program. The fiscal deficit of $16.0 million 
(5.1% of GDP) in FY2020 was largely funded by government cash reserves, but the $93.4 million 
deficit (33.1% of GDP) in FY2021 will require debt financing to avoid placing extreme pressure on 
government cash reserves. The ADB anticipates the borrowing required to sharply increase public 
net debt from the equivalent of 16.7% of GDP in FY2019 to 43.8% by the end of FY2021. 
 
11.  Pressure on jobs and household incomes. The latest available data shows tourism-
related sectors accounted for 2,729 jobs in 2016 (36.7% of the total workforce), representing 
about half of all non-public sector employment, including informal labor.10 The public sector 
accounted for a further 26.5% of the workforce, with other retail services (17.0%) and construction, 
manufacturing, and utilities (10.1%) making up most of the remainder. The Cook Islands has high 
formal employment, with only between 4.3% and 12.4% of the total workforce engaged in informal 
work. Women comprise 60.5% of tourism-related jobs, and the sector accounts for 63.3% of all 
jobs held by women. With tourism-related jobs at risk, there is a risk of substantial development 
progress unwinding. The 2016 Household Income and Expenditure Survey estimates that 8.4% 
of the population falls below the basic needs poverty line, down from 28.4% in 2006. A further 
13.6% of the population was defined as vulnerable in 2016, falling from 40.0% in 2006.11 With

12.  Gender equality gains at risk. In the event of COVID-19 infections, women are at an 
increased risk of infection because of their role as frontline health workers and care givers. Indirect 
risks include worsening health outcomes if essential services, such as maternal and reproductive 
health and noncommunicable diseases, are de-prioritized. Socioeconomic impacts for women 
include increased poverty from loss of income. Women in the Cook Islands earn 8.0% less than 
men, work more part-time, and carry more of the burden of unpaid care and household tasks. 
Women represent 60.5% of the workers in tourism-related businesses. Data pre-pandemic shows 
that around one-third of all households are headed by women; and that these households, have 
incomes around 18% lower on average than households headed by men. Households headed by 
elderly women are particularly vulnerable to low income and social isolation, and households 
headed by women face increased risk of poverty. The economic pressures of COVID-19 will 
worsen this. Gender-based violence (GBV) service providers have experienced an increase in 
the number of domestic violence cases being reported since the onset of COVID-19.13 The 
collection and use of sex-disaggregated data are limited.  
 
13.  Comprehensive countercyclical expenditure program. The ERP aims to mitigate the 
impacts of COVID-19 on livelihoods and local businesses, including vulnerable households, in a 
way that does not undermine the government’s ability to carry out further fiscal intervention.14 The 
ERP is financed in two phases: (i) NZ$42.6 million ($28.0 million, 8.6% of GDP) for FY2020, and 
(ii) NZ$89.7 million ($59.0 million, 20.9% of GDP) for FY2021. The four themes of the ERP are (i) 
COVID-19 medical response and preparation (paras. 14–15), (ii) lifeline measures to support 
livelihoods through support to households and businesses (paras. 16–21), (iii) recovery measures 
that  can  help  kickstart  growth  (paras.  22–23),  and  (iv)  transformation  measures  to  help 
businesses (para. 23) (Table 3).

B. Proposed Program, Impact, and ADB’s Value Addition
26. The aim of the Cook Islands ERP is to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on livelihoods 
and local businesses, including vulnerable households, in a way that does not undermine the 
government’s ability to undertake further fiscal intervention if needed (footnote 2). ADB’s CARES 
Program will support the ERP by delivering the following outputs: (i) the health care system’s 
COVID-19 response measures strengthened, (ii)  livelihoods  protected by compensating for 
economic losses, and (iii) economic relief for affected businesses delivered. The program will 
contribute toward achieving an outcome where the adverse impacts of COVID-19 on the Cook 
Islands’ population and businesses are reduced to alleviate the pressure on the government’s 
fiscal position. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.
27. ADB’s value addition. The program is part of wider ADB support covering the immediate 
response to COVID-19, short-term financing needs, and ongoing technical assistance (TA) to 
support the government response. ADB provided support for the initial fiscal impacts of the crisis 
by disbursing $10.06 million under the Cook Islands Disaster Resilience Program.28 The Asia 
Pacific Disaster Response Fund provided $1 million, and ADB TA provided a further $270,000 for 
PPE and essential medical equipment to respond to immediate health needs.29 The CARES 
Program contributes to the short-term financing need created by the ERP, particularly in FY2021. 
To enable the lending and credit measures of the ERP to proceed, ADB TA supported the drafting 
of the COVID-19 (Economic Response) Act 2020.30 The ADB has undertaken a rapid social 
assessment to evaluate the potential impacts of COVID-19 on vulnerable groups and the impacts 
of government income support.31 This supported the program by facilitating improved access to 
gender-disaggregated data and guided the targeting of future ADB TA, including providing 
capacity in gender and social assistance, budget planning, policy capacity, and data collection.32
28. Regional cooperation and integration. The CARES Program supports Cook Islands’ 
regional cooperation and integration by providing support to tourism businesses (paras. 20–23) 
that should enable regional tourism to recover more quickly, and support for the livelihoods of 
migrant workers (paras. 16–19). The ADB support should also be seen in the broader context of 
ongoing and planned ADB operations that include the completion of the Manatua submarine cable, 
connecting  the  Cook  Islands  to  global  telecommunications  infrastructure,  investments  in 
sanitation and renewable energy to safeguard the pristine environment, and planned upgrades to 
Rarotonga airport. The Cook Islands is already engaged with New Zealand on the formation of 
safe contained travel arrangements, with neighboring countries potentially following the Cook 
Islands’ template. Cooperation with New Zealand border and health officials is well advanced.

34.  Debt  sustainability.  The  Cook  Islands’  public  debt  is  almost  wholly  external,  with 
domestic debt at only 1% of total public debt. External public debt net of the Loan Reserve Fund 
fell from 26.4% of GDP in FY2016 to 16.7% by FY2019. Accumulated fiscal surpluses resulted in 
an increase in the general reserve to the equivalent of 19.8% of GDP at the end of FY2019. This 
reduced the need for external financing in the immediate response to the COVID-19 crisis, 
although the heavy economic and fiscal impacts of COVID-19 will require debt financing from 
FY2021 onwards (with the general reserve exhausted), bringing net debt to an estimated 43.8% 
in FY2021. ADB’s DSA shows that debt will maintain on a steady downward trend as the economy 
recovers from the third quarter of 2021, even under conservative economic growth assumptions 
in the medium term. The loan is also not seen to add significantly to annual debt service 
obligations facing the government. Therefore, ADB’s DSA concludes that the Cook Islands’ public 
debt remains sustainable and fiscal vulnerabilities will likely be contained over the medium term.36

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
36.  Governance. The Cook Islands has a strong history of sound fiscal management, with 
strong fiscal anchors supporting the limited use of debt and the accumulation of fiscal buffers. 
The 2015 Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability assessment noted the strength of the 
Cook Islands’ budget process and documentation, financial monitoring and reporting, financial 
reconciliation,  transparency  in  the  tax  system,  and  public  access  to  information. 39  The 
assessment  also  noted  weaknesses  in  multiyear  budget  planning,  commitment  controls, 
monitoring fiscal risks, timely audit reports and procurement. The government has pursued 
reforms through its Public Financial Management road map for 2016–2020 supported by the IMF 
Pacific Financial Technical Assistance Centre.40 The following proven government systems are 
being used to implement the ERP: the tax system for income assessments, the electronic 
settlements between the Treasury and the Cook Islands National Superannuation Fund, existing 
online platforms for business applications and payments, and the existing fortnightly social welfare 
system for additional cash payments. The areas of implementation outside existing government 
systems, such as concessional lending initiatives, are being managed on a commercial basis 
through domestic banks that are overseen by the Financial Services Commission. ADB will 
provide  further  implementation  support  (para.  27).  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as 
amended to date) was explained to the government and MFEM. 
 
37.  Poverty. The rapid social assessment commissioned by ADB showed that COVID-19 has 
heightened existing social inequities in the Cook Islands. The potential disruption of social 
services and increased social isolation heightened the vulnerability of the elderly (15% of the 
population), people with disabilities (28% have at least one form of disability), and people with 
pre-existing conditions (24% of the population). The assessment stated that the government has 
effectively  targeted  its  income  support  to  the  working  population  most  likely  to  become 
unemployed and to those receiving social welfare payments who were already vulnerable. 
Employment measures and grant support for sole traders are open to informal and migrant 
workers (predominantly women) who are particularly vulnerable and may not have means of 
support during the business downturn. The free education initiatives will support the ability of 
formal and informal workers to improve lifetime incomes. Challenges remain for providing services 
to people with disabilities and those in the outer islands, which have much more limited access to 
health services and telecommunications, increasing their vulnerability to COVID-19 disruptions.

1. Adverse impact of The Cook Islands is one of the most tourism-dependent countries in the region, with 
exogenous tourism receipts equivalent to 61.4% of GDP in 2019. With the shutdown of international 
shocks travel, GDP is estimated to have fallen 7.0% in FY2020, down from 5.3% growth in 
FY2019. If borders open to tourism in January 2021, then it is anticipated that GDP will fall 
a further 15.4% in FY2021, with persistent and extreme risks to this outlook. These are 
the largest economic contractions in Cook Islands history and will continue to have a 
profound impact on unemployment, business viability, government finances, and Cook 
Islands society. The tourism-related sectors account for around 2,730 jobs (or 36.7% of 
the total workforce) representing around half or all non-public sector employment—these 
jobs are at risk the longer the shutdown continues. The public sector is the other major 
contributor to the economy, but government revenue will also face significant declines, 
falling an estimated 41% in FY2021 as compared to FY2019 levels. Combined with 
stimulus measures, ADB estimates a fiscal deficit of 33.1% of GDP in FY2021 which will 
place government cash reserves under increasing pressure, even with ADB support. The 
slow anticipated recovery in international tourism will continue to weigh on revenue in 
FY2022  and  beyond,  potentially  forcing  the  Government  to  undertake  significant 
expenditure cuts.

3. Pre-shock record Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Cook Islands was implementing sound economic 
of generally sound policies. The fiscal balance has averaged 5.7% of GDP and GDP growth has averaged 
macroeconomic 6.7% between FY2016–FY2019. Successive fiscal surpluses have enabled the creation 
management of fiscal buffers (the Stabilisation Account: NZ$56.7 million, 11.4% of GDP prior to COVID-
19 in FY2020) and a sinking fund to smooth debt servicing requirements and aid in better 
cash management (the Loan Reserve Fund: NZ$21.4 million, 4.3% of GDP; around 2 
years-worth of debt servicing requirements in FY2020).  Revenue has performed strongly, 
especially following tax reforms in 2014, with domestic revenue increasing from 39.1% of 
GDP in FY2016 to 41.0% of GDP in FY2019. Expenditure has been largely contained, 
averaging 37.5% of GDP in the FY2016–19 period. Public debt net of the Loan Reserve

4.  Structural reforms  Strong actions in the form of early travel restrictions and social distancing have prevented 
(including health  a COVID-19 outbreak. The Cook Islands Emergency Response Plan to COVID-19 has 
response)  laid out a pandemic preparedness and management plan, including tiered systems for 
pandemic response and management and widespread testing. The Ministry of Health 
(MOH) activated its Health Emergency Response system on 22 January 2020, denying 
entry to travelers from affected countries later that month with the border closed on 24 
March. Mandatory 14-day quarantine, school closures, domestic travel suspensions and 
social distancing were enforced during the lockdown period.  Widespread testing began in 
mid-March, with the Cook Islands declaring itself COVID-19 free on 16 April 2020. 
Lockdown restrictions were relaxed on 20 April. Community transmission of COVID-19 in 
New Zealand on 11 August 2020 reinitiated border control measures, although social 
distancing measures were not reimposed. Domestic travel remains open. 
 
The fiscal response and economic support measures have been integrated into, and have 
aimed to strengthen, existing systems, including social protections and public health 
services. The Economic Response Plan (ERP) represents approximately 29.5% of GDP 
across FY2020 and FY2021 and aims to preserve the capacity of the economic sector in 
order to accelerate an eventual economic recovery. It does this by allowing businesses to 
remain operational and preserve their payroll whilst meeting their debt obligations. The 
COVID-19 (Economic Response) Act 2020 was passed to authorize and legislate policy 
responses where needed, particularly those measures relating to credit and lending 
initiatives. The Ministry of Health has indicated that it will likely continue and expand the 
community-based health services commenced during the COVID-19 response, as well as 
improvements to mental health services, and possible long-term reforms to elder and 
disability care. 
 
The Cook Islands has been a vocal and proactive partner in trying to establish an 
international ‘travel bubble’ with its major tourist source market of New Zealand, but no 
timeline has been set. 
5.  Debt sustainability  The Cook Islands is a group C country and not rated as a high risk of debt distress prior 
to the pandemic, but suffers similar issues to other Pacific small island states on account 
of its vulnerability and narrow economic base. Following the pandemic, drawdowns of 
fiscal buffers will be complemented by an increase in debt financing from the ADB and

the government debt ceiling of 35%, although debt net of the Loan Reserve Fund will reach 
this level by FY2024.b The Cook Islands does not have a central bank or direct access to
